head.title: SUPERWIND MODEL OF EXTENDED LYMANŒ± EMITTERS AT HIGH REDSHIFT

article.h1: SUPERWIND MODEL OF EXTENDED LYMANŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha EMITTERS AT HIGH REDSHIFT

span.span: Astronomical Institute, Graduate School of Science, Tohoku University, Aramaki, Aoba, Sendai 980-8578, Japan

div.p: We propose a new model for the extended LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha blobs found recently at high redshift z‚àºsimilar-toùëßabsentitalic-z RELOP:similar-toz\sim 3. The observational properties of these blobs are; 1) the observed LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha luminosities are ‚àº1043‚Å¢h-2similar-toabsentsuperscript1043superscript‚Ñé2RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:43 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim 10^{43}h^{-2} ergs s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, 2) they appear elongated morphologically, 3) their sizes amount to ‚àºsimilar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 100 kpc, 4) the observed line widths amount to ‚àº1000similar-toabsent1000RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1000\sim 1000 km s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, and 5) they are not associated with strong radio-continuum sources. All these observational properties seem to be explained in terms of galactic winds driven by successive supernova explosions shortly after the initial burst of massive star formation in the galactic centers. The observed number density of LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha blobs (‚àº3.4√ó10-5‚Å¢h3similar-toabsent3.4superscript105superscript‚Ñé3RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:3.4 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim 3.4\times 10^{-5}h^{3} Mpc-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3}) may be explained if their present-day counterparts are elliptical galaxies with a luminosity above ‚àº1‚Å¢L*similar-toabsent1superscriptùêøRELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim 1L^{*}.

article.div: galaxies: formation - galaxies: evolution - galaxies: starburst - stars: formation

div.p: Recent great progress in the observational astronomy have revealed that a large number of high-redshift galaxies can be accessible by continuum emission of galaxies (stellar continuum, thermal continuum from dust grains, or nonthermal continuum from plasma heated by supernovae) in a wide range of observed wavelengths between optical and radio (e.g., Williams et al. 1996; Lanzetta, Yahil, & Fern√°ndez-Soto 1996; Chen, Lanzetta, & Pascarelle 1999; Steidel et al. 1996a, 1996b; Dey et al. 1998; Spinrad et al. 1998; Weymann et al. 1998; van Breugel et al. 1999; Smail et al. 1997; Hughes et al. 1998; Barger et al. 1998; Eales et al. 1999; Barger, Cowie, & Sanders 1999; Richards et al. 1999). On the other hand, it has been also argued often that forming galaxies at high redshift experienced very luminous starbursts and thus they could be much brighter in line emission such as LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha and [O ii]ŒªùúÜitalic-lambda\lambda3727 emission lines (e.g., Partridge & Peebles 1967; Larson 1974; Meier 1976). However, although many attempts have been made to search for such very strong emission-line sources at high redshift (see for a review, Pritchet 1994; see also Pahre & Djorgovski 1995; Thompson, Mannucci, & Beckwith 1996), most these searches failed except some successful surveys around known high-zùëßitalic-zz objects such as quasars (Hu & McMahon 1996; Hu, McMahon, & Egami 1996; Petitjean et al. 1996; Hu, McMahon, & Cowie 1999). Very recently, a new attempt with the Keck 10 m telescope has revealed the presence of LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha emitters in blank fields at high redshift (Cowie & Hu 1998, hereafter CH98). Subsequently, Keel et al. (1999, hereafter K99) and Steidel et al. (1999, hereafter S99) also found a number of high-zùëßitalic-zz LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha emitters in other sky areas. Since these three surveys have reinforced the potential importance of search for high-zùëßitalic-zz LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha emitters, it seems urgent to investigate the origin of LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha emitters.

section.h3: 1.2 Extended Lyman Œ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha Emitters at High Redshift

div.p: A brief summary of the recent three surveys for high-zùëßitalic-zz LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha emitters (CH98, K99, and S99) is given in Table 1. In this Letter, we adopt an Einstein-de Sitter cosmology with a Hubble constant H0=100‚Å¢hsubscriptùêª0100‚Ñéitalic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:100 italic-hH_{0}=100h km s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1} Mpc-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}. Each survey has discovered more than ten strong LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha emitters with the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha equivalent width above 100 √Ö¬† in the observed frame. It is interesting to note that five sources among them are observed to be very extended spatially, e.g., ‚àºsimilar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 100 kpc (K99; S99); we call them LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha blobs following S99 (hereafter LABs). These five sources are cataloged as Object 18, Object 19, 53W002 (K99), Blob 1, and Blob 2 (S99). Their basic data are given in Table 2. Since the three LABs found in K99 are all strong C iv emitters (Pascarelle et al. 1996), it seems natural to conclude that they are photoionized by the central engine of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) (K99). On the other hand, the remaining two LABs found by S99 have no evidence for the association with AGNs (S99). It should be also noted that their observed LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha equivalent widths, E‚Å¢W‚Å¢(Ly‚Å¢Œ±)ùê∏ùëäLyùõºitalic-E italic-W OPEN:( Ly italic-alpha CLOSE:)EW({\rm Ly}\alpha) ‚àºsimilar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 1500 √Ö, are much larger than those of the three K99 sources. These suggest that the origin of LABs may be heterogeneous and thus the origin of S99 LABs is different from that of K99 ones.

Here we summarize the observational properties of the LABs found by S99; 1) the observed LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha luminosities are ‚àº1043‚Å¢h-2similar-toabsentsuperscript1043superscript‚Ñé2RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:43 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim 10^{43}h^{-2} ergs s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, 2) they appear elongated morphologically, 3) their sizes amount to ‚àºsimilar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 100 h-1superscript‚Ñé1italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endh^{-1} kpc, 4) the observed line widths amount to ‚àº1000similar-toabsent1000RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1000\sim 1000 km s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, and 5) they are not associated with strong radio-continuum sources such as powerful radio galaxies. One possible origin may be that these LABs are superwinds driven by the initial starburst in galaxies because i) a superwind could develop to a distance of ‚àºsimilar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 100 kpc in the low-density intergalactic medium (IGM), and ii) a superwind often blows with a bi-conical morphology (e.g., Heckman, Armus, & Miley 1990). In this Letter, we investigate this possibility. We also discuss a possible evolutionary link between LABs and high-zùëßitalic-zz, dust-enshrouded submm sources (Barger et al. 1999 and references therein).

We consider the possibility that a LAB is a well-developed superwind seen from a nearly edge-on view. First, we investigate properties of a superwind caused by the initial starburst in a galaxy. We adopt the dissipative collapse scenario for formation of elliptical galaxies and bulges [i.e., the monolithic collapse model111It is not necessarily to presume that this pregalactic cloud is a first-generation gigantic gas cloud. If a number of subgalactic gas clouds are assembled into one and then a starburst occurs in its central region, the physical situation seems to be nearly the same as that of the monolithic collapse. (Larson 1974)] together with the galactic wind model proposed by Arimoto & Yoshii (1987; hereafter AY87; see also Kodama & Arimoto 1997). In this scenario, the initial starburst occurs at the epoch of galaxy formation in the galaxy center. Subsequently, massive stars die and then a large number of supernovae appear. These supernovae could overlap and then evolve into a so-called superbubble. If the kinetic energy deposited to the surrounding gas overcomes the gravitational potential energy of the galaxy, the gas clouds are blown out into the intergalactic space as a superwind (e.g., Heckman et al. 1990).

The evolution of such a superwind can be described by superbubble models (McCray & Snow 1979; Koo & McKee 1992a, 1992b; Heckman et al. 1996; Shull 1995). The radius and velocity of the shocked shells222It is noted that the derivation of rshellsubscriptùëüshellitalic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start shell POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{\rm shell} requires that the baryonic component dominates the gravitational potential. Although the presence of a dark matter halo requires that this estimate of rshellsubscriptùëüshellitalic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start shell POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{\rm shell} is not valid at arbitrarily large radii, we do not take account of this effect because our discussion is an order-of-magnitude one. at time tùë°italic-tt (in units of 108superscript108NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end10^{8} years) are then

div.p: where Lmechsubscriptùêømechitalic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start mech POSTSUBSCRIPT:endL_{\rm mech} is the mechanical luminosity released collectively from the supernovae in the central starburst in units of 1043superscript1043NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:43 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end10^{43} ergs s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1} and nHsubscriptùëõHitalic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{\rm H} is the average hydrogen number density of the IGM in units of 10-5superscript105NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end10^{-5} cm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3}.

We can estimate Lmechsubscriptùêømechitalic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start mech POSTSUBSCRIPT:endL_{\rm mech} directly from AY87. For an elliptical galaxy with a stellar mass Mstars=1011‚Å¢M‚äôsubscriptùëÄstarssuperscript1011subscriptùëÄdirect-productitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start stars POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:11 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm stars}=10^{11}M_{\odot}, radius r‚âÉsimilar-to-or-equalsùëüabsentitalic-r RELOP:similar-to-or-equalsr\simeq 10 kpc and nH‚àº1similar-tosubscriptùëõH1italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1{n}_{\rm H}\sim 1 cm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3} (Saito 1979; AY87), we expect NSN‚àº3√ó109similar-tosubscriptùëÅSN3superscript109italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start SN POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:3 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:9 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN_{\rm SN}\sim 3\times 10^{9} stars that explode as supernovae. Since most of these massive stars were formed during the first 5√ó1085superscript108NUMBER:5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end5\times 10^{8} years (= tGWsubscriptùë°GWitalic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start GW POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{\rm GW}), we obtain Lmech‚àºŒ∑‚Å¢ESN‚Å¢NSN/tGW‚àº1043‚Å¢erg‚Å¢s-1similar-tosubscriptùêømechùúÇsubscriptùê∏SNsubscriptùëÅSNsubscriptùë°GWsimilar-tosuperscript1043ergsuperscripts1italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start mech POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to italic-eta italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start SN POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start SN POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start GW POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:43 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end erg s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endL_{\rm mech}\sim\eta~{}E_{\rm SN}~{}N_{\rm SN}/t_{\rm GW}\sim 10^{43}~{}{\rm erg% ~{}s}^{-1} where ESNsubscriptùê∏SNitalic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start SN POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{\rm SN} is the total energy of a single supernova (1051superscript1051NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:51 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end10^{51} ergs) and Œ∑ùúÇitalic-eta\eta is the efficiency of the kinetic energy deposited to the ambient gas (‚àºsimilar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 0.1; Dyson & Williams 1980). We assume for simplicity that a hydrogen number density in the IGM is We thus obtain nIGM‚Å¢(3)‚âÉ7.3√ó10-5‚Å¢h-2similar-to-or-equalssubscriptùëõIGM37.3superscript105superscript‚Ñé2italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start IGM POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:3 CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:7.3 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endn_{\rm IGM}(3)\simeq 7.3\times 10^{-5}h^{-2} cm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3} at z=3ùëß3italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:3z=3. Since we assume that the superwind is seen from a nearly edge-on view, we obtain a characteristic size of the superwind, l‚àº2√órshell‚àºsimilar-toùëô2subscriptùëüshellsimilar-toabsentitalic-l RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:2 MULOP:times italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start shell POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-tol\sim 2\times r_{\rm shell}\sim 150 kpc with nH,-5=7.3subscriptùëõH57.3italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H PUNCT:, ADDOP:minus NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:7.3n_{\rm H,-5}=7.3. If we assume an opening angle of the superwind Œ∏open=45‚àòsubscriptùúÉopensuperscript45italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start open POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:45 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\theta_{\rm open}=45^{\circ} (see section 2.3), we obtain a full width at half maximum velocity of the superwind, FWHM ‚àº2√óvshell‚Å¢sin‚Å°Œ∏open‚âÉ620similar-toabsent2subscriptùë£shellsubscriptùúÉopensimilar-to-or-equals620RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:2 MULOP:times italic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start shell POSTSUBSCRIPT:end TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start open POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:620\sim 2\times v_{\rm shell}\sin\theta_{\rm open}\simeq 620 km s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}. These values appear consistent with the observations (S99).

section.h3: 2.2 Frequency of Occurrence of Superwinds at High Redshift

div.p: Since our superwinds model implies that the most probable progenitors of LABs are forming elliptical galaxies, it is important to compare the observed number density of LABs at high redshift with that of elliptical galaxies in the local universe. The observed number density of LABs at high redshift can be related to the number density of elliptical galaxies responsible for the LABs nE-LABsubscriptùëõELABitalic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start E ADDOP:minus LAB POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{\rm E-LAB} as

semantics.annotation: italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start LAB POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start E ADDOP:minus LAB POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start SW POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus Delta Omega MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 italic-pi CLOSE:) PUNCT:,

div.p: where ŒΩSWsubscriptùúàSWitalic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start SW POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\nu_{\rm SW} is the chance probability to find superwinds from high-zùëßitalic-zz ellipticals, and Œî‚Å¢Œ©ŒîŒ©Delta Omega\Delta\Omega is the full opening solid angle of a pair of the superwind in units of steradian. The last term is attributed to the assumption that we observe superwinds from a nearly edge-on view.
First, based on the results of CH98, K99, and S99, we estimate nLABsubscriptùëõLABitalic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start LAB POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{\rm LAB} using the following relation,

semantics.annotation: italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start LAB POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start LAB POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( CH98 CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start LAB POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( K99 CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start LAB POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( S99 CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start italic-V OPEN:( CH98 CLOSE:) italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cl POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( CH98 CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-V OPEN:( K99 CLOSE:) italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cl POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( K99 CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-V OPEN:( S99 CLOSE:) italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cl POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( S99 CLOSE:) ARG:end

div.p: where Vùëâitalic-VV is the co-moving volume of the surveyed area (see Table 1) and fclsubscriptùëìclitalic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cl POSTSUBSCRIPT:endf_{\rm cl} is the clustering factor of galaxies in the surveyed volume with respect to the so-called field. In the CH survey, no LAB is found in the two blank fields; i.e., NLAB‚Å¢(CH98)=0subscriptùëÅLABCH980italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start LAB POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( CH98 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0N_{\rm LAB}({\rm CH98})=0 and fcl‚Å¢(CH98)=1subscriptùëìclCH981italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cl POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( CH98 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:1f_{\rm cl}({\rm CH98})=1. In the S99 survey, the two LABs are found in the proto-cluster region in which the number density of galaxies is higher by a factor of ‚âàRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 6 than that in the field; i.e., NLAB‚Å¢(S99)=2subscriptùëÅLABS992italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start LAB POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( S99 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:2N_{\rm LAB}({\rm S99})=2 and fcl‚Å¢(S99)=6subscriptùëìclS996italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cl POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( S99 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:6f_{\rm cl}({\rm S99})=6. In the K99 survey, although the three LABs are found in the 53W002 field, all of them are associated with AGNs. Therefore, we adopt NLAB‚Å¢(K99)=0subscriptùëÅLABK990italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start LAB POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( K99 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0N_{\rm LAB}({\rm K99})=0. There is a rich group of galaxies in this field (Pascarelle et al. 1996). However, since it is difficult to estimate its clumping factor quantitatively, we assume fcl‚Å¢(K99)‚âÉfcl‚Å¢(S99)=6similar-to-or-equalssubscriptùëìclK99subscriptùëìclS996italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cl POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( K99 CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to-or-equals italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cl POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( S99 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:6f_{\rm cl}({\rm K99})\simeq f_{\rm cl}({\rm S99})=6. We do not use the data of the other five fields surveyed by K99 because the detection limits of LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha emission are higher by a factor of 2 than those of the other survey fields. Then we obtain nLAB‚âÉ3.4√ó10-5‚Å¢h3similar-to-or-equalssubscriptùëõLAB3.4superscript105superscript‚Ñé3italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start LAB POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:3.4 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endn_{\rm LAB}\simeq 3.4\times 10^{-5}h^{3} Mpc-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3}.

Next we estimate the probability to observe superwinds ŒΩSWsubscriptùúàSWitalic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start SW POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{m SW}. Since galaxies beyond z‚àº5similar-toùëß5italic-z RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:5z\sim 5 have been found (e.g., Hu et al. 1999; Dey et al. 1998; Spinrad et al. 1998; Weymann et al. 1998; van Breugel et al. 1999), we assume that elliptical galaxies were formed randomly at a redshift range between z=10ùëß10italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:10z=10 and z=3ùëß3italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:3z=3. According to the cosmology model adopted here, the above redshift interval corresponds to a duration of œÑform‚âà6.4√ó108‚Å¢h-1subscriptùúèform6.4superscript108superscript‚Ñé1italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start form POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:6.4 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end	au_{m form}\approx 6.4	imes 10^{8}~{}h^{-1} years. For an elliptical galaxy with a mass of 1011‚Å¢M‚äôsuperscript1011subscriptùëÄdirect-productNUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:11 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product POSTSUBSCRIPT:end10^{11}M_{\odot}, the galactic wind breaks at t‚Å¢(SW)‚âÉ3.5√ó108similar-to-or-equalsùë°SW3.5superscript108italic-t OPEN:( SW CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:3.5 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endt({m SW})\simeq 3.5	imes 10^{8} years after the onset of the initial starburst (AY87). Therefore, superwinds could be observed from such ellipticals with z‚â≤6less-than-or-similar-toùëß6italic-z RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:6z\lesssim 6. The chance probability of superwinds can be estimated as ŒΩSW=œÑSW/œÑformsubscriptùúàSWsubscriptùúèSWsubscriptùúèformitalic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start SW POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start SW POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start form POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{m SW}=	au_{m SW}/	au_{m form} where œÑSWsubscriptùúèSWitalic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start SW POSTSUBSCRIPT:end	au_{m SW} is the duration when a superwind can be observed as an emission-line nebula. As shown in section 2.1, a duration of œÑSW‚âà1√ó108subscriptùúèSW1superscript108italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start SW POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end	au_{m SW}\approx 1	imes 10^{8} years is necessary to develop the superwind to a radius of ‚àº100‚Å¢h-1similar-toabsent100superscript‚Ñé1RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:100 italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim 100h^{-1} kpc. Therefore, we obtain ŒΩSW‚âÉ0.16‚Å¢hsimilar-to-or-equalssubscriptùúàSW0.16‚Ñéitalic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start SW POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:0.16 italic-h
u_{m SW}\simeq 0.16h.

Thirdly, we estimate the probability to observe superwinds from a nearly edge-on view. A typical semi-opening angle of superwinds may be Œ∏open‚âÉ45‚àòsimilar-to-or-equalssubscriptùúÉopensuperscript45italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start open POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:45 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\theta_{\rm open}\simeq 45^{\circ} (e.g., Heckman et al. 1990; Ohyama, Taniguchi, & Terlevich 1997 and references therein). This gives 1-Œî‚Å¢Œ©/4‚Å¢œÄ=cos‚Å°Œ∏open‚âÉ0.711ŒîŒ©4ùúãsubscriptùúÉopensimilar-to-or-equals0.71NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus Delta Omega MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 italic-pi RELOP:equals TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start open POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:0.711-\Delta\Omega/4\pi=\cos\theta_{\rm open}\simeq 0.71.
Then, we obtain

math.alttext: n_{\rm E-LAB}\sim n_{\rm LAB}\nu_{\rm SW}^{-1}(1-\Delta\Omega/4\pi)^{-1}\sim 3% .0\times 10^{-4}~{}h^{2}~{}{\rm Mpc}^{-3}.

semantics.annotation: italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start E ADDOP:minus LAB POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start LAB POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start SW POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus Delta Omega MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 italic-pi CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:3.0 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Mpc POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.
n_{\rm E-LAB}\sim n_{\rm LAB}\nu_{\rm SW}^{-1}(1-\Delta\Omega/4\pi)^{-1}\sim 3% .0\times 10^{-4}~{}h^{2}~{}{\rm Mpc}^{-3}.

div.p: Integrating the luminosity function of elliptical galaxies derived by Marzke et al. (1994), we find that the above number density corresponds to that of ellipticals above ‚âÉ1‚Å¢L*similar-to-or-equalsabsent1superscriptùêøRELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:1 italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\simeq 1L^{*} when h‚Ñéitalic-hh lies in a range between 0.5 and 1. Since the mass of an elliptical galaxy with L*subscriptùêøitalic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUBSCRIPT:endL_{*} is ‚àº1011‚Å¢M‚äôsimilar-toabsentsuperscript1011subscriptùëÄdirect-productRELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:11 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sim 10^{11}M_{\odot} (AY87; Kodama & Arimoto 1997), our superwind model appears consistent with the observations.

Finally we give comments on the visibility of galaxies hosting superwinds. In our superwind model, the central starburst region may be obscured by the surrounding gas and dust. Although AY87 assume that the superwind blows isotropically for simplicity, actual superwinds tend to have a bi-conical morphology. This implies that a lot of gas and dust may be located in the host galaxy with a disk-like configuration, being responsible for the collimation of superwinds. These gas clouds are expected to absorb the radiation from the central star cluster if we observe superwinds from a nearly edge-on view. Let us consider a case that gas clouds with a total mass of MgassubscriptùëÄgasitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start gas POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm gas} are uniformly distributed in a disk with a radius of rùëüitalic-rr and a full height of dùëëitalic-dd. We estimate the average number density of gas nH=Mgas/[œÄ‚Å¢r2‚Å¢d‚Å¢mH]‚âÉ14‚Å¢Mgas,10‚Å¢r10-2‚Å¢d1-1subscriptùëõHsubscriptùëÄgasdelimited-[]ùúãsuperscriptùëü2ùëësubscriptùëöHsimilar-to-or-equals14subscriptùëÄgas10superscriptsubscriptùëü102superscriptsubscriptùëë11italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start gas POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide OPEN:[ italic-pi italic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:14 italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start gas PUNCT:, NUMBER:10 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:10 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endn_{\rm H}=M_{\rm gas}/[\pi r^{2}dm_{\rm H}]\simeq 14M_{\rm gas,10}r_{10}^{-2}d% _{1}^{-1} cm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3} where Mgas,10subscriptùëÄgas10italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start gas PUNCT:, NUMBER:10 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{\rm gas,10} is in units of 1010‚Å¢M‚äôsuperscript1010subscriptùëÄdirect-productNUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product POSTSUBSCRIPT:end10^{10}M_{\odot}, r10subscriptùëü10italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:10 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{10} is in units of 10 kpc, d1subscriptùëë1italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endd_{1} is in units of 1 kpc, and mHsubscriptùëöHitalic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{\rm H} is the mass of a hydrogen atom. This gives an H i column density NH=nH‚Å¢r‚âÉ4.2√ó1023‚Å¢Mgas,10‚Å¢r10-1‚Å¢d1-1subscriptùëÅHsubscriptùëõHùëüsimilar-to-or-equals4.2superscript1023subscriptùëÄgas10superscriptsubscriptùëü101superscriptsubscriptùëë11italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-r RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:4.2 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:23 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start gas PUNCT:, NUMBER:10 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:10 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN_{\rm H}=n_{\rm H}r\simeq 4.2\times 10^{23}M_{\rm gas,10}r_{10}^{-1}d_{1}^{-1} atoms cm-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2} for an edge-on view toward the gas disk, corresponding to the visual extinction of AV‚àº280similar-tosubscriptùê¥ùëâ280italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:280A_{V}\sim 280 mag where we use a relation of AV‚Å¢(mag)=NH/(1.54√ó1021‚Å¢cm-2)subscriptùê¥ùëâmagsubscriptùëÅH1.54superscript1021superscriptcm2italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( mag CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide OPEN:( NUMBER:1.54 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:21 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end cm POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)A_{V}({\rm mag})=N_{\rm H}/(1.54\times 10^{21}~{}{\rm cm}^{-2}) (e.g., Black 1987). Even if the gas-to-dust mass ratio is ten times smaller than that of our galaxy, the visual extinction is still large, AV‚àº30similar-tosubscriptùê¥ùëâ30italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:30A_{V}\sim 30 mag. This may be responsible for the observed shortage of the ultraviolet luminosities accounting for the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha line luminosities (S99).

The obscuration described above may also be responsible for the observed large equivalent widths of the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha emission in S99; i.e., E‚Å¢W‚Å¢(Ly‚Å¢Œ±)‚àº1500similar-toùê∏ùëäLyùõº1500italic-E italic-W OPEN:( Ly italic-alpha CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1500EW({\rm Ly}\alpha)\sim 1500 √Ö. Since these LABs are observed at z‚âà3.1ùëß3.1italic-z RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:3.1z\approx 3.1 (see Table 2), the rest-frame equivalent widths are estimated to be E‚Å¢W0‚Å¢(Ly‚Å¢Œ±)‚àº375similar-toùê∏superscriptùëä0Lyùõº375italic-E italic-W POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( Ly italic-alpha CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:375EW^{0}({\rm Ly}\alpha)\sim 375 √Ö. This value is still larger by a factor of two than those expected for star-forming, dust-free galaxies; e.g., E‚Å¢W‚Å¢(Ly‚Å¢Œ±)‚âÉsimilar-to-or-equalsùê∏ùëäLyùõºabsentitalic-E italic-W OPEN:( Ly italic-alpha CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to-or-equalsEW({\rm Ly}\alpha)\simeq 50 ‚Äì 200 √Ö¬† (Charlot & Fall 1993; see also Tenorio-Tagle et al. 1999). However, in our model, strong continuum radiation from the central star cluster can be obscured by a lot of surrounding gas and dust. On the other hand, the LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha emission arises from the superwind which is far from the host, e.g., r‚àºsimilar-toùëüabsentitalic-r RELOP:similar-tor\sim 100 kpc. Therefore, the larger-than-normal E‚Å¢W‚Å¢(Ly‚Å¢Œ±)ùê∏ùëäLyùõºitalic-E italic-W OPEN:( Ly italic-alpha CLOSE:)EW({\rm Ly}\alpha) is one of important properties of our model.

section.h3: 2.4 A Possible Evolutionary Link Between LABs and Dust-enshrouded Submm Sources

div.p: As mentioned in section 2.2, the central starburst region in a forming elliptical galaxy could be enshrouded by a lot of gas with dust grains because these grain are expected to be supplied either from Population III objects (if any) or first massive stars in the initial starburst or both. Therefore, elliptical galaxies at this phase may be observed as dust-enshrouded (or dusty) submm sources (hereafter DSSs). Subsequent supernova explosions blow out the gas into the IGM as a superwind several times 108superscript108NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end10^{8} years after the onset of the initial starburst. Elliptical galaxies at this superwind phase are assumed to be LABs in our model. We note that they are expected to be much fainter at submm than the DSSs because a significant part of dust grains were already expelled out from the galaxy. In summary, the dissipative-collapse formation of elliptical galaxies together with the galactic wind model suggests the following evolutionary sequence. Step I: The initial starburst occurs in the center of pregalactic gas cloud. Step II: This galaxy may be hidden by surrounding gas clouds for the first several times 108superscript108NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end10^{8} years (i.e., the DSS phase). Step III: The superwind blows and thus the DSS phase ceases. The superwind leads to the formation of extended emission-line regions around the galaxy (i.e., the LAB phase). This lasts for a duration of ‚àº1√ó108similar-toabsent1superscript108RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim 1\times 10^{8} years. And, Step IV: The galaxy evolves to an ordinary elliptical galaxy ‚àº109similar-toabsentsuperscript109RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:9 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim 10^{9} years after the formation.

The origin of LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha emission from high-zùëßitalic-zz objects may be heterogeneous; i.e., a) ionized gas irradiated by massive stars, b) ionized gas heated by superwinds, and c) ionized gas irradiated by the central engine of various types of AGNs. Such diversity is also reported for submm-selected galaxies (i.e., DSSs) with z>1ùëß1italic-z RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:1z>1 (Ivison et al. 1999). Therefore, in order to investigate the cosmic star formation history from high-zùëßitalic-zz to the present day (e.g., Madau et al. 1996), we will have to study carefully what the observed LyŒ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha emitters at high redshift are.

We would like to thank an anonymous referee for useful suggestions and comments. YS is a JSPS fellow. This work was financially supported in part by the Ministry of Education, Science, and Culture (Nos. 07044054, 10044052, and 10304013).
